Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Situation2: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Story:
I was lacing up my sneakers, ready for my late-night gym session—part of my commitment to staying fit as a police officer. My phone buzzed, and I saw it was Sam, my oldest friend. His voice was shaky, almost frantic. “My car broke down on the highway. It’s dark, and I’m scared. Can you come get me? Please, man, I don’t know what to do.”

As a friend, I knew what was expected of me. Sam had always been there for me, and now he needed me. But as a police officer, I also had a duty to myself and the community to maintain my fitness, to be ready for whatever the job threw at me. Missing another workout would set me back, and I’d promised myself—and my captain—that I wouldn’t let my physical standards slip.

I stared at my gym bag, then at my keys. The weight of both uniforms—one of friendship, one of duty—pressed down on me. My heart pounded, torn between the call for help and the call to serve. I stood there, caught in the headlights of my own conflicting roles, unsure which road to take.
